La Belle was founded by four people, eager to push the videogame medium forward. Author of interactive fictions, and of the dark adventure game "Out There", Fibre Tigre will supervise the game design of our games.

Thibaut de Corday. A french producer of films, videogames, documentaries and short programs with a political or societal meaning. His latest production is documentary and a videogame based on science fiction iconic author, Philip K. Dick.

Cedric Bache. After more than 15 years, as a head of business developpment at Neko Entertainement, Cedric is a veteran of the indie scene. He's involved in the french and european indie scene, but he and his team aslo helps young teams to finalize their games.

Laurent Checola. After a first career, employed at Le Monde, he became "indie journalist" working on webdocumentaries and game projects. Let's Play ! is a five episode serie about the European videogame indie scene, published by Devolver on Steam.

We will make games but also organize events related games with content. Our first event is called "Mediajam" : 8 journalists collaborated with confirmed game developers to create unique gameplays during the french presidential campain.

Byer Steel is a customer-oriented scrap metal recycling center and rebar mill in Cincinnati, providing industrial and retail customers with convenient, no-hassle recycling solutions. Since 1937, major industrial operations and individuals alike have turned to these professionals for all of their recycling needs. Their experience in the industry allows them to process a wide variety of metals and produce some of the highest-quality steel rebar products on the market.

Manufacturers, fabricators, demolition companies, and maintenance shops all benefit from Byer Steel’s roll-off container services, tailored to the size and level of activity at your operation. They have many container sizes available, and promise a high level of service and quick payment turnarounds.

Unlike most retail metal recycling centers, which lack customer service and cleanliness standards, Byer Steel provides a clean, well-maintained facility with drive-through recycling services and immediate payment. They accept almost any type of metal, including brass, aluminum, steel, iron, and even lead at very competitive prices.

In addition to their industry-leading recycling program, Byer Steel is also the only domestic commercial producer of axle grade rebar, made exclusively from recycled train axles. Their products are available in a variety of shapes and strength grades, and can even be custom made to suit any application.

Game Development and Innovation Center, Calaris Studio was established in November 1993 by Zieliński brothers. At the very beginning of its activity Calaris Studio was known as TSA Proprietary Software Development. The first computer game published on polish market was "Rooster". The most significant, legendary computer game magazine “Top Secret", announced this product in January 1994 as “the first polish true fps…" We received also Playbox fair award for the debut of the year. During next two years, we created series of games on Amiga platform. Among them were such issues as “Dan Wilder" and “Intercalaris" nominated as the game of the year, because of its unique and highly efficient graphic engine.

In this period Calaris Studio decided to start cooperation with other PC game studios.
Joining efforts with Elysium Images we began production of “Net Guard", and with Corwin Software Studio we worked at “Mortyr", which appeared to be the great success - world wide known popular computer game.

Thanks to great experience, advanced technology, and well-prepared, determinated employees Calaris Studio has been enjoying its renaissance. Since that time it has been regularly preparing high-quality products providing entertainment for players spread all over the world.

Nowadays Calaris is a rapidly developing company represented by two experienced, well-organized design teams with leading publishers as its clients.

Category : Kids Camps, Recreational Camps, Summer Camps

Every summer in a child’s life should be unforgettable. A summer at camp can be filled with opportunities for learning to be independent, for social and activity skills development, for building relationships and for just pure fun! While some of these personal growth-minded tools can be developed in school, programs aimed at reaching these goals are rarely built around aspects of fun as a priority. For more than fifty years, Camp Eagle Hill in Elizaville, NY has been providing summers of fun, challenge and excitement while helping its campers to grow both socially and emotionally.

Staffed with teachers, parents, coaches, and other professional adults, we provide a high quality program in a nurturing environment. Eagle Hill features a wide array of activities including a full sports program, a strong waterfront program, an extensive creative arts program, a lively theater program and many individual activities like go karts, archery, cooking, gymnastics, nature, mountain biking, climbing tower and much more! Each camp day is capped off with a fun and exciting evening event such as talent shows, Las Vegas Night, DJ Parties or MTV Night. Weekly trips and special events add a little more excitement to a well-rounded sleepaway camp experience.

Our camp welcomes boys and girls between the ages of 6-16. High quality supervision is of utmost importance to us, with staff-to-camper ratios set typically at two camp counselors for every seven or eight children. This ensures that each child is always well cared for and given individual attention. Our directorship takes a personal interest in the life of each and every CEH camper and prides itself on knowing all of the details that will help the individual camper to be successful while at camp.

Give your child the opportunity to build lifelong friendships and enjoy summers filled with fun, laughter and camaraderie. Call us at Camp Eagle Hill today at (914) 725-4876, email us at summer@campeaglehill.com, or visit our webpage for more details on our camp program.

Cherry Picked Games is a small tabletop game company based out of Seattle, WA.

Our debut project is Catalyst, a role playing game set during a demon apocalypse in modern society. We saw a lot during the four years of playtesting it endured: amazingly creative characters, heartfelt debate over ethical dilemmas, gut-wrenching in-game betrayal of other players, ingenious problem solving, and the single worst die roll possible (a one in the game master's scotch). These playtesters drove us past our $10,000 Kickstarter goal and let Catalyst exist. There is currently an Android app to assist players with character creation, inventory management, and battle tracking. The iOS version of the player app will be available soon, and a GM assistant app for both platforms is expected by the end of this year.

The next Cherry Picked project, Drink!, is in development. Drink! is a drinking game with easy rules, guaranteed to run people through an emotional gamut. This little box of cards will see laughter, bewilderment, fear, and triumph over the evening. Best of all, it is an addition to the event, not a focal point. Play during a house party, board game night, wedding reception, or whatever social gathering needs a touch more intrigue and inebriation.

We also strive to help the tabletop game community however we can. From actively participating in Washington's board game scene to hyping up the hobby on air, we want everyone to roll some dice and tell some stories. Our site hosts a blog about improving your experience with role playing games to help neophytes and veterans alike (please ask us whatever gaming questions you have). We also want to help out other indie game developers out there by providing consulting or contractor work for writing, illustrations, graphic design, app development, production, playtesting, or whatever else is blocking more great games from the public.

The current CPG staff is:

  • Alexander Jerabek – Creative Director
  • Jake Breish – Drink Artist
  • Kaylee Breshon and Adam Zerby – Catalyst Mobile Developers
  • Bennett Durfee – Catalyst Artist

Bio

Hello, my name is Dawson and i'm an indie developer. While you're here you should go ahead and download The Roamers or The Calling and give me some feedback on it. Thanks!

The Roamers

The Roamers is an Apocalyptic Top Down RPG where you venture out from your secluded cabin in search of what happened to the world. The story is barely started and we're currently working on the gameplay elements of it (character animations, keybinds, and pause menus). If you're looking for a more complete game this isn't for you, but feedback, reccomendations, and support are very appreciated. If you're looking to help out with the game, see the Help Wanted section below.

The Calling

The Calling is a 2d Platformer where you search the depths of the Atlantic for a lost amulet in a ship named the Santa de Frey. This game was made for The Weekly Game Jam and production lasted for only 6 short days. Keep that in mind at the end of the game where things are a bit rushed.

Developers

These games were made by my team and people who worked with us over certain projects.

  • Me (you're already on my page)
  • Adwitr
  • SomeFarang

Help Wanted

If you'd like to collaborate with me and Adwitr on The Roamers (music, voice actor, character artist, or any type of artist except UI) then send me an email - theroamersgame@gmail.com. Thanks!

I'm Catherine, an aspiring video game writer from Montreal, Quebec.

As a writer, I particularly appreciate beautifully written games like Life is Strange or anything from Telltale. I also have a soft spot for the Halo series since they're the first Xbox games I've ever played.

I've been writing for a long time, but it's only recently that I've decided to combine my two passions. I now write for a French blog, Geektualité, that focuses on anything geeky or video game-related and I'm looking for a position as a game writer in the Montreal video game industry.

And now, enough talk. Time to play video games!

Most people do not know what they can do for themselves to help their situation, so our game will aim to teach students about what they can do to help them feel more like themselves. Feeling happy and stress-less is very important in order to have a healthy life. We want to do just that; provide people with strategies to get them as close as we can to a healthy life.

Who are we?

We at EverGreen are a pair of indie developers, one artist and one programmer.

What did we do?

We attended a 2 year video game development course based in Cambridge where we learnt the fundamentals of game development.

What are we doing?

Now stepping out into the real world we seek people to help us continue to do what we've always dreamed of doing.

Where are we going?

Having learnt the basics and been given a year to develop our projects we are now heading to E3 to show off our games.

You can find us at the Rizing Games stall (located between Capcom and Alienware in the South hall).

We are very excited and look forward to meeting you all

-The Devs
Hey all ! My name is Anis Chouk, and I'm a french graphist trying to make a step in the video game industry :)

Welcome to 11th Dimension Entertainment, makers of the classic RPG series "Excelsior." If you are a fan of old-school, classic adventures, you have come to the right place! Our games are:

Excelsior Phase One: Lysandia

Excelsior Phase One: Lysandia is the first in a series of role-playing games designed in the spirit of the iconic Ultima series. Excelsior combines the look and feel of classic role-playing games with an intricate story line.

Excelsior Phase One: Errondor

Excelsior Phase Two: Errondor, as you may have guessed, is the sequel to Excelsior Phase One. It features a redesigned interface, all new art, and sets a new standard for shareware RPGs.

Skyland's Star

Skyland's Star is a text adventure game in the spirit of the classic Zork series. With a sophisticated parser, a huge map, and an intriging story line, Skyland's Star will be a welcome trip down memory lane for long time gamers.

Check out a part of my older work:

Theyre gonna bomb the whole downtown area (was what i thought). The power flicked back on just in time for us to see the building coming down - are we far enough way? I saw the words "potential terrorist attack on WTC"S" scroll accross the screen. I mean - these were tall buildings - now Im gonna die a few blocks away? God dammit why did I come to work - why didnt I just keep on running in the opposite direction and get as far away as possible? As the buildings came down the entire downtown area turned BLACK - from smoke. Suddenly it occurred to us that this much smoke could be a problem. That would be my luck - i get out of the building - escape falling debris - twice - avoid burning cars - only to sit here and be concerned about dying from smoke inhalation?!?! Are you kidding me? We began to take down the curtains and wet them and hold them over our faces. All I could hear were explosions and things banging around outside. I was sure I was going to die - absolutely sure. I called my grandmother and mother and let them know what was going on. We were headed to the basement so this could be the last time we speak. There are no words to describe this feeling. I had to get out of here alive. I just HAD to. After a little while I couldnt take not knowing what was going on. After all, even though we were only a couple of blocks away from the WTC, we were also a couple of blocks away from the Hudson river. Do i think Im a good enough swimmer to make it to Brooklyn - I dunno. But Ill be damned if I sit here and choke to death. People were already coughing. Anyone with asthma was definitely having a hard time. Ive got to be honest here - i think the fact that I was a smoker actually worked in my favor. I was having a much easier time than some dealing with the smoke. I went to the gound floor - looked outside into the blackness - thought for a moment what the quickest way to the river was - I convinced my friend Julie to come. It was pitch black outside - there was about a foot of muck all over the roads - it was like quicksand - so i definitely wouldnt be running anywhere. But we made it to the river and low and behold - there sat a boat - are you kidding? We were yelling and waving and it was like we had hit the lottery. We hitched a ride to NJ and at that point it was 2pm - almost 5 hours of utter hell - was now getting better. I consider myself very lucky and fortunate. Lets be grateful for what we have. As it could all be taken away in the flick of a switch.

3D modeler and aspiring game designer. I really care about representation of different people and it is a goal I hope to explore in my larger projects.

When growing up I was exposed to many things in media and in my constant moving as a child. But I always saw how my culture was never really represented, and when a close culture to mine was it was often in negative light. This has changed over time, and I am glad to see a rise in work produced by Latinx creators. But I still think back to my childhood, my time with my grandmother,  and my tiny home country of El Salvador. 

I think of all the other cultures as well, which are often overlooked in media despite how interesting they can be,and I hope someday to collaborate with people from there, and help bring their worlds to the forefront.

Hello! My name is Marvin Hawkins, a hobby game developer from Chicago.  Everyone who wants to make games probably faced that moment of truth. The moment that you decide to stop enjoying them as a consumer and want to actually create them. I’m sure that sounds like one of those TV art school commercials, but its true. Mine was at a very early age. I was playing Super Mario Brothers 3, and decided I want to do this. As a 5 year old child I was not sure what ‘it’ was. Not knowing how games were made, I spent much of my youth making little board games out of shoe boxes. I would also spend whole saturdays creating concepts for games, drawing levels, etc. My parents were slightly terrified. ‘People don’t get paid for making games’  The older I got, the more that I understood that games weremade by people. In high school, I learned how to program in visual basic, and started tinkering with level design tools. I knew that I was hooked.

I spent my college years at the Illinois Institute of Art getting my BFA in Game Art and Design. Art in games is stunning, but my true passion is Game Design and Programming. This web site is designed to capture all of my game development projects, and the learning that comes out of it. I sincerely hope that my mistakes/findings can help others.

I love games, sports, books, and art. I love the feeling that you get when someone is enjoying your creation. The only other feeling that is better than creation is seeing someone play your work. Any questions, just ask.

Hubert's Hideout is a competitive local multiplayer game for 2 players. In the first phase, each player hides cubes of the opponent's colour, which turn invisible when placed. In the second phase, the players try to find the cubes of their own colour with the help of the controller's rumble feature as a ping or detector. When a player is near to a cube, they can make it visible with a special detector sphere. When a cube is found, they can be placed under one of the stations to capture them. The player with three captured stations wins!

Developed by:

Brett Ayo - game design, concept art, sound design

Maximilian Haas - game design, character design, texture & concept art

Zwi Zausch - game design, programming, modelling, texturing & shading


Hubert's Hideout was created as a third semester project at the Game Design study program at HTW Berlin and is in constant development since.

We thank our coaches Susanne Brandhorst, Thomas Bremer and Sven Gorholt for their invaluable support for this project.

If you are interested in programming video games and independent game development then this group is for you! We hold lectures on video game programming techniques and promote the development of games by groups of developers. Artists (2D and 3D) as well as Audio engineers who want to get into game development also welcome!

We hold two meetings every month, one every two weeks. The first meeting is usually a tutorial meeting where the group members decide the topic and sometimes even give the lecture. The second meeting is an open development (meet and great meeting), where club members come into to discuss what they are working on, get help, guidance, or look for other like minded individuals to help contribute.

We are currently working with Unity 4.x both 2D and 3D. We cover a wide range of topics for beginners up to advanced topics. If you have any questions please send a message to David Brown or Shawn Paris the founders of the Guild of Independent Game Developers through the meetup site.

We also occasionally put together unique game jams throughout the year.  Please go to the link above to find out more information.

When I was around 10 years old, my step father gave me a Nintendo Gameboy Advance SP. Besides Tetris, Dig Dug, and other various arcade games, the very first video game I ever played was the original Legend of Zelda ported for the Gameboy. Since that moment, I not only developed a passion for Zelda games, but a passion for video games in general.

Here is where I'll mostly be cataloging my misadventures in game development, going over what I'm working on, possibly some concept art, etc.

I won't pretend to be great, hell I won't even pretend to be proficient, but I do have some experience in pixel art (my primary go-to for art) and programming. For game development, I primarily use Game Maker Studio 2, however I do know bits and pieces of other languages (C++, Python, JS, etc.) but GM2 is just where I'm most comfortable.

Hey! I'm Lenni, but you can call me Len for short. I am an aspiring game dev currently in college to get a degree in computer programming. I love video games, surfing the web, sleeping, creating art, and making stories! Right now, I have no experience with programming games other than just using different RPG Maker versions to create an outline for the games that I want to make in the future when I have the experience. Whenever I get the tools to start making professional looking games, I will probably start posting my creations and art on this platform.

Back in the day, I would always love to draw. I would draw different characters from many Touhou games, many characters from many different anime series, and also some other characters that I would create in my head. I also had an extreme love for RPGs like Pokemon, Dragon Quest, Mario, etc. It wasn't until my freshman year of high school where I decided to combine my love of video games, drawing, and creating stories into one. It was right there, I realized that being a game developer was the right career choice for me.

I would like to consider myself to be a solo developer, which I know, for all of you solo workers out there, it's pretty hard work. I hope that my dreams will come true, and that I would be able to create games that everybody will love.


regards //

                - lenni

About Me:

29 year old Canadian dude who likes to make games. 

Skills:

Programming in C#, Java, PHP, Python, and more. I prefer to use C# and Unity, as I've been using them for close to 7 years, except for a couple years in the middle where I was working on finding a medication regime that worked well. I can barely do vector art in Inkscape, but I can make decent enough art for me to prototype with more than just blocks. I also look out for free CC0 art that I can use to make my games look better. 

Goals:

I want to just make a bunch of small games, in rapid succession, until I find something that I can expand on well enough to get a job working remotely that will cover my medication and bring in a bit more than the small amount the government gives me. The plan is to replace being on reddit with making games and keeping myself busy, and sober.

|April, 2018 - I just released the first content of my equally first game project, "Rob, The Dog!". "Rob" is a classic 2D platformer-syle game, with polished and clean scenarios, and interesting mechanisms of gameplay. It's easy to play "Rob" but not that easy to beat "Rob", know what I mean? It´s very easy to like "Rob", that's for sure. It's a funny game. It's a pure game. It's a good casual personal non-commercial game.
And I invite you to try it!
Go ahead, don't be shy! :)
This first release comes with the first six levels of action and adventure of our cute little hero-dog, Rob. And like I'm right now working on the creation of more levels, it's very true to say that more and more updates (not only new levels but also new game functionalities) will become available soon and from times to times.
So............
Stay tuned for more "Rob, The Dog!" soon!

----------

|May, 2018 - This should had been a kind of "secret" but, whatever, here goes: I'm working on a side game project called "Drag It!". I don't want and I will not reveal much more about this new project now, but I intend to make it available for download during the next month of May.
I already have the full storyline script ready and a good part of the main objects required for the project.
As my current main priority is "Rob, The Dog!", I can't really make promises about this new side-project, but I'm confident about a first release during these next weeks.
Let's see how things go... :)

I'm Mitchell Rutherford indie developer for my small company Zario Games, We have yet to complete a game but are working on two projects...

Vigilance, Vigilance is a FPS in very early stages of development. Its an open world game with simple FPS gameplay. We have implemented a large open world based off a fictional Scandinavian nation. We have so far implemented several vehicles to get around with including boats, cars and planes. I am currently working health systems and other gameplay aspects such as life and health. The game will have a well rounded political back story revolving around a world that has been changed heavily by warfare, Where hundreds of new nations have been formed fighting for the dominance for there political view and philosophy. You are a member of an organization that sends its highly trained members around the world to use violence to restore peace.

Benchmark, Our benchmark uses various rendering techniques to put strain on your PC, Straining Ram, CPU and graphics. With a choice of various resolutions and graphics settings for you to adjust and change. The benchmark still has a way to go till its a finished product but its well in development and ready for alpha use.

The Game Design program at Moorpark College provides core competencies in the cultural, theoretical, artistic, and narrative aspects of game design, as well as a broad background in the creation and development of playable media. The program is designed to prepare students for freelance careers and/or entry-level employment as independent game developers or with game design and development companies. Students explore creative, technical, critical, and design-based solutions to real world issues in order to meet the rigors of a dynamically evolving array of game-oriented professions.

Both an A.S. degree and Certificate of Achievement are available in Game Design.

The mission of the Games for Entertainment and Learning (GEL) Lab at Michigan State University is to design innovative prototypes, techniques, and complete games for entertainment and learning and to advance state of the art knowledge about social and individual effects of digital games. The GEL Lab is an association of game research and design faculty and students, primarily in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences. The lab focuses on externally funded research and development work and employs graduate and undergraduate students.

The GEL Lab is part of the larger GameDev@MSU effort that involves research, outreach, and teaching. The undergraduate program in game design was ranked #7 and graduate #8 by Princeton Review in 2018.

Hello! My name is Ashley Muir, I am a student attending SAE/Qantm studying Game Design and aim to be finished end of 2016. I have currently started the final project for Uni which last for 6 months. I am the Designer and Producer of this team, managing 7 people from multiple disciplines (Audio, Animation, Programming, ect).

I am also the Designer and Producer of a team currently developing and publishing our first mobile game, managing 4 people. This is a 12 week project aimed to get a better idea of the business side of software development, honing in on our target market, how to gain funding to support the studio, ect.

I have a passion for 2D games and how old Sega games have evolved from where they were to now games such as Braid, Fez and Hyper Light Drifter.

Uni: Final Project Game

For our final project game, Neonknight, we will be making a 2D action based game using your swordspear as a close-quarters fighting tool, a long ranged traversal tool and a gap closeing tool (throwing your swordspear will impale a wall or enemy allowing you to pull yourself to that location or pulling the enmy to you, kind of like a grappling hook). This will allow the player to use their weapon for more than just offensive/defensive, expanding the flexibility of gameplay.

You play as a Neonknight, the last of your kind. Once side by side of other Neonknights, you protected the city for years, but when high ranked, money grabbing companies thoughts they were "Too good", creating 'accidents' to frame the Neonknights, eventually shutting them down and were replaced by new robots, lead by the cash consuming companies. After all these years, you are the last one, Looking to finish off what the Neonknights started.

2.5D Story Telling in "Inside"

Recently, have have had an intrest in story telling through 3D environments due to looking at an Indie game named "Inside". This game uses no voice lines and very minimal text to teach the player new mechanics as well as hint story elements in the background. Its a linear 2.5D platformer, but due to how open the game surrounds the 3D world around the player, it enforces the player to include the 3D as part of the gameplay mechanics

Original Doom and how they use their enemies.

For our final project game, I decided to bring ideas from the first doom game through their enemy system and put that into 2D environment. Making the player quickly scan the assortment of enemies to plan ahead how they should take them out.

I got this idea from watch Game Maker's Toolkit video about doom and what we can learn from it (Click here for the video!). He talks about how each enemy has a particular way to kill them, what they are strong as, as well as how they can all be killed. What we can take from this is in each level of our final project game, we will introduce enemies in various way using multipul uses of traversal side of the weapon as well as the melee side of the weapon

Brand new games games for the classic Atari 2600 video entertainment system. Can be played in any Atari 2600 emulator.

An Atari 2600 emulator is required to play this game. Stella is the best for PC, MAC, Linux/UNIX and many other platforms. Get it at this link:

http://stella.sourceforge.net/

Stella is a freely distributed multi-platform Atari 2600 VCS emulator; originally developed for Linux by Bradford W. Mott, it is now maintained by Stephen Anthony. Stella allows you to enjoy all of your favorite 2600 games once again by emulating the 2600's hardware with software. Stella is written in C++, which allows it to be ported to other operating systems and architectures. Since its original release Stella has been ported to AcornOS, AmigaOS, DOS, FreeBSD, Linux, MacOS, OpenStep, OS/2, Unix, and Windows, as well as consoles such as Sega Dreamcast, GP2X, Nintendo DS and Playstation Portable (among others).

Nicholas O’Brien is a net-based artist, curator, and writer researching Games, Digital Art, and Network Culture. His work has exhibited in Mexico City, Berlin, London, Dublin, Italy, Prague, as well as throughout the US. He has been the recipient of a Turbulence Commission funded by the NEA and has curated exhibitions at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, 319 Scholes, and Eyebeam Center for Art and Technology. As a contributor to Rhizome at the New Museum, and Artsy, he has been recognized as a leading voice within contemporary art by Art F City, PULSE art fair, and AQNB. His work has also appeared or featured in ARTINFO, The Brooklyn Rail, DIS magazine, Frieze d/e, The Atlantic, and The New York Times. He currently lives in Brooklyn and is Assistant Professor in 3D Design and Game Development at Stevens Institute of Technology.

Mike Odum grew up in Roanoke, Virginia where he began cutting his artistic teeth on chalkboards and the edges of notebook paper. Throughout his elementary and middle school years teachers became increasingly concerned for Mike's future, telling his parents that "Drawings of robots and gun-wielding characters is strange behavior, and will likely get him arrested one day." Luckily this never happened and Mike was able to stumble his way through high school with only sketchbooks and drawing tools.

Not long after graduation, Mike decided to attend Virginia Western Community College instead of joining the circus as a caricature artist. After two bootcamp style years studying graphic design at VWCC and freelancing, Mike turned his ambitions towards the big, little city, Richmond, Virginia where he enrolled in VCU's Communication Arts Department. Comm Arts proved to be Mike's home planet at last. There he studied comics, concept art, and illustration. The combination of all these studies and his unique skill set eventually lead Mike to SRRN Games where he produced mobile games and applications and worked with prestigious publishers such as South Peak Interactive, Chillingo, Konami, and Sony.

Today Mike has co-founded his own game company ROOT 76, with others from SRRN and is back to his freelance roots doing illustration, design, and comics. His bright future ahead, Mike is ready to work and form new business partnerships, having recently been quoted as saying "Without a doubt, if you are paying for art, you should give me your money."

Hello, my name is Jeremy and I create RPG Maker Horror games as a hobby. Looking for a game that is not necessarily scary but is disturbing and unnerving? A game that focuses on the aspects of darkness, subtle disturbing changes during gameplay, and challenging puzzles? Are you interested in playing a storyline spread across a single universe? Then you've come to the right place.
   Delve into my world and discover how the end of Earth came to fruition. Play as Drey or another character based in the "Jugular" series to see different points of view of the apocalypse. Learn of the growing menace transforming innocent people into disgusting, hulking, beasts of blood and torture. Survive in this world and learn of their exponential growth, not just physically...but mentally as well. I hope you enjoy this series as much as I enjoyed creating them.

I will make games.... when I want to, and when I can be bothered to... so that means I won't be making games often....

Feel free to make monetised videos on my games

My Games:

The games are in order of which they were made, Banana Crazy was the first game I ever made (so its not that good) but feel free to criticise it and tell me how bad it is. The 2 worst games I have made would be: Toast Troubles and En Routé which were both made for a 1 hour game jam (which explains why they are so bad.) The 2 best game I think I have currently made would be: NIGHTMARE SIMULATOR.exe which is a definitely not scary horror game, and: SHADED is a short but weird platformer. The game I am currently working on is: Magnetic Heights which is a short low-poly spy game. So far its over 60% complete and will definitively be the best game I have ever made which shall hopefully come out this September. So far I haven't made any games that cost money to play they are all free to play BUT you can donate money if you like/enjoy the game which would be very much appreciated... (I don't think any of my games are worth any money though tbh.)

Game Development:

I use the Blender Game Engine to create my games which I know isn't a proper game engine but I use it because I know how to use it and because no coding is necessary. All of my games are created in the low-poly style mainly because I am better at making low-poly assets and because in my opinion it looks better. I don't create games often because I prefer to make YouTube videos instead and school decides to take up a lot of my time so when I do make games I make them when I really want to (which hopefully makes them better.) Fore example the game I am currently working on (Magnetic Heights)  will have a gameplay time of 10 - 15 minutes even though I first had the idea for Magnetic Heights in 2014... yeah a while ago I know. But the game should be coming out this September... I hope.

Me (Nathan Richardson):

I am a British teenager who for some reason sometimes enjoys creating indie games even though I dislike AAA games and bought a PS4 several years ago and haven't turned it on for 2 years... but I enjoy indie games so that should hopefully be good. I spend a lot of my spare time creating or watching YouTube videos (sub to my YouTube channel plz if you enjoy stupid stuff: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpcW1QbLyA2QppQ9VWZdCfQ) Most of my time is wasted at school and occasional a little bit of homework so I only have time to make video games when I am not at school, not making or watching YouTube videos, not being lazy and not when I don't want to make indie games. If anyone wants to contact me or talk about my games then feel free to DM me on twitter: @mrmangomonster or say something in the discussion part of my games.

FAQ:

"Whats your favourite game??" - My favourite indie game would have to be Gravity Bone and the best AAA game would have to be Far Cry 3.

"What game engine do you use??" - I use Blender Game Engine.

"How would you recomend I get into game development??" - Learn to use Unity as it is the best game engine for indie developers.

Hardware:

I have a pretty simple setup with a laptop I bought at Christmas in 2015 hooked up to a rather big television which helps a large amount with game development and video editing. Specs: Intel i5 processor, 8gb of RAM and a 2tb hard-drive.

DRN.001 ロックマン（Rockman）
声優：椎名へきる（CDドラマ、パワーバトル 他） - 折笠愛（ロックマン8、スーパーアドベンチャー 他） - 藤野かほる（VS.シリーズ） - 小椋美輝（ガンスパイク） - 小林由美子（ロックマンロックマン）
本作の主人公。元はライト博士に作られた家庭用お手伝い人型ロボット「ロック」だったが、平和を守るために自ら志願して戦闘用に改造された。
頭には超小型電子頭脳、体にはEPロムと基板、超小型R.S.動力炉（ライトソーラーパワーパイル）を内蔵。頭から太陽エネルギーを取り入れ、動力源とする。関節は磁力関節。耳にはキャッチ用の3つの穴が空いている。足のサスペンションと空気圧力ポンプにより、ジャンプ調整やスライディングが可能。腕は、戦闘時に拳が収納されて銃口が飛び出し、太陽エネルギーを圧縮した弾「ソーラーブリット」を放つ武器「ロックバスター」に変形する。その所要時間はわずか1/1000秒。両腕ともバスターに変形可能だが、エネルギーが強力なため、片方ずつしか撃てない。後にエネルギー増幅装置が装備され、太陽エネルギーを凝縮したチャージショットの使用が可能になった。ロックバスターの武器可変システムにより、倒したボスの武器チップをロックバスターに組み込むことで、様々な武装を使用できるようになる。特殊武器を切り替えるとロックマンの色が変わるが、これはボディのコーティング素子がプリズム状になっており、特殊武器装備時にR.S.動力炉から発生する特殊な波長がその屈折率を変えるためである。
プレイステーション版『MARVEL VS. CAPCOM』においては、唯一ボスキャラクターの技を習得してパワーアップする演出があり、本家であるロックマンシリーズの様な武器習得デモが用意され、別バージョン扱いで選択すると実際に使用できる。
任天堂の『大乱闘スマッシュブラザーズ for Nintendo 3DS/Wii U』にゲスト参戦。通常ワザ・必殺ワザでシリーズ各作品に登場したボスの特殊武器を使用できる。特殊武器使用時に色は変わらないが、カラーバリエーションで特殊武器選択中のカラーリングを再現できる。「最後の切りふだ」は『9』のブラックホールボムで相手を異次元空間へ吸い込んだ後、歴代のロックマン（『ロックマンX』のエックス、『ロックマンDASH』のロック、『ロックマンエグゼ』のロックマン、『流星のロックマン』のロックマン）が出現して一斉にバスターを放つ「ロックマンスペシャル」。場外に吹っ飛んだり転落した時に原作同様のやられ演出がある。
名前の由来は、音楽のロックンロールから。
日本国外での名称は「Mega Man」（メガマン）。日本名のRockmanと違い、二語に分けて書く。変更の経緯について、当時カプコンのアメリカ法人で役員(シニア・バイス・プレジデント)を務めていたJoseph Moriciが、Rockmanという名称が気に入らず「最悪の名称だ」と評したことから行われたということが、1993年のゲーム雑誌のインタービューにて明かされている。

This page is home to VR, music, and video from the world of SATELLITES

Structurally informed by “The Canterbury Tales,” SATELLITES  introduces a variety of travelers who share their tales and motivations as they journey across a fictional planet's vast ocean.

Each character travels alone on board their own vessel, docking with others for the briefest periods of time.  It is during these moments of contact and dialogue that we learn elements of the characters' stories and enter their memories. Even as each character reveals an obvious motivation for making such a journey --perhaps for the sake of science, art, or leisure-- the viewer gets glimpses of deeper, more hidden drives behind their self-imposed exiles. 

 Oculus and Cardboard compatible projects coming soon!

Six Times Nothing is an indie game developer based in Sydney, Australia.

Founded by Creative Lead, Sándor Moldán in 2009, we have worked across a range of projects with an array of talented people including helping other developers realise their games, producing middleware and asset solutions for games – and ultimately our own major game project, Dawn of the Tyrant.

Dawn of the Tyrant is an indie game development project led by creator, Sándor Moldán and supported by a number of talented creators across the globe. The project is significantly advanced with a fully-functional alpha version and a collection of fantastic characters and artwork.

Our goal is to launch the first chapter of Dawn of the Tyrant in 2018 and follow up with more chapters as the story unfolds. To turn our alpha into a fully fledged game, we will be reaching out to our base of followers and the game community for support and plan to launch a crowdfunding campaign in the early months of 2018.

He creates games and software tools as part of his design practice.

This is a showcase of games created by students studying in our Bachelor of Serious Games (or related majors/minors) at the University of the Sunshine Coast.

Serious games are more than ‘just a game’. With new opportunities emerging in education, healthcare, marketing and more, this diverse field is one of the fastest growing and most exciting sectors of the games industry. This unique program lets you build and apply skills in game design and development to address a range of social problems – using the universal appeal of play.

  • Collaborate with fellow game writers, artists, programmers and designers to produce and publish serious games that meaningfully connect with players and address global needs
  • Analyse the meanings and cultural implications of gameplay and story, and use this knowledge to create emotionally rich and challenging games
  • Get hands-on experience in developing for PC, smartphones and tablets, augmented reality and virtual reality

Hi! My name is Joseph Perry, aka Wick. I am an independent game developer and neuroscientist.

I grew up on a blueberry farm in the Columbia River Gorge, graduated from Reed college with an undergraduate degree in biology (with a thesis on the neuroscience of frog mating calls), and now reside in Portland, OR Oakland, CA.

I'm a self-taught programmer (in the Blitzmax / Monkey X family of languages — it's OK, they're pretty obscure, you probably haven't heard of them) and manage to get by via copious googling and transmuting bugs into features.

Starship Rubicon is my first published game. You shoot things in a spaceship and end up feeling uneasy about shooting things in spaceships.

I decided at a young age that I'd structure my life towards working towards the problem of artificial intelligence. I think node-based neural nets are cool, but are rooted in an over-simplification of the brain due to historical computational limitations. Thus, I've been approaching the problem of AI with a foot solidly in biology.

I believe in using games (and art, for that matter) for doing good in society. To me, this means designing for accessibility, listening to and incorporating diverse voices as well as I am able, and crafting an experience that betters the player's life.

Hi.

When I was five, I folded games consoles out of paper. The games were drawn on paper "cartridges" which would slot behind a tracing-paper screen. At ten, I made a "first person shooter" in Powerpoint by using timed slides and hyperlink enemies. Then I discovered Blitz Basic, unlocking the world of actual programming. Level up!

I've since made games with Java, Python, C++ and ActionScript among other languages. For my masters project, I designed and implemented hardware-accelerated, networked multiplayer Tetris on FPGAs. Most recently I've been using Haxe and HaxeFlixel.

I enjoy game jams and working in a team, but when a team was not available, I often found myself making my own art and sound assets. Now I love it all, and will happily work in any of these roles.

I'm also a magician.

A freeform game designer based in NYC. Occasional judge/helper for the Golden Cobra Contest.


Other projects I've contributed towards

I co-designed See Me Now with Liz Gorinsky, a game about exploring gender. See Me Now was played at Fastaval in 2016.

I wrote a variant setting for The Skeletons, a meditative freeform game by Jason Morningstar.
